Knowledge Point: Kuā\is{kua (collective)@kuā (collective)} (etymology unknown; there is also a less common variant koā\is{koa (collective)@koā (collective)}, which does not occur in older texts) indicates a human collectivity, a group of people belonging together. With a singular noun, as in examples \REF{ex:5.8} and \REF{ex:5.9} below, it has an associative sense \citep[50]{Dixon2012}: kuā N means ‘N and the ones around him/her, N and the others’. When the noun itself has plural reference, as in (\ref{ex:5.10}–\ref{ex:5.13}) below, kuā refers to ‘the group of N’.
Content 1: \gll Pē ira a \textbf{kuā} \textbf{Tiare} i iri ai ki \ꞌuta e tahi mahana. | \gls like ANA PROP COLL Tiare PFV ascend PVP to inland NUM one day | \glt ‘Thus Tiare and the others went to the countryside one day.’
Content 2: \gll He nonoho \textbf{a} \textbf{kuā} \textbf{koro} he kakai. | \gls NTR PL:sit PROP COLL Dad NTR PL:eat | \glt ‘Dad and the others sat down and ate.’
Content 3: \gll E Tiare, e hāpa\ꞌo rivariva koe i a \textbf{kuā} \textbf{māhaki}. | \gls VOC flower EXH care_for good:RED 2SG ACC PROP COLL companion | \glt ‘Tiare, take good care of the little ones.’
Content 4: \gll Ko \textbf{kuā} \textbf{tō\ꞌoku} ŋā poki taina rikiriki era ko tō\ꞌoku pāpārū\ꞌau era. | \gls PROM COLL POSS.1SG.O PL child sibling small:PL:RED DIST PROM POSS.1SG.O grandfather DIST | \glt ‘We were with my little brothers and my grandfather.’

Knowledge Point: In short, kuā occurs before the same words which can also be preceded by the proper article\is{a (proper article)} a, i.e. proper nouns (\sectref{sec:3.3.2}). This may have led \citet[474]{DuFeu1987} to classify kuā as a proper article\is{a (proper article)} as well. However, kuā is different from the proper article\is{a (proper article)}. As examples \REF{ex:5.8}, \REF{ex:5.9} and \REF{ex:5.10} show, kuā can co-occur with the proper article\is{a (proper article)}. This indicates that the two do not belong to the same class of particles, but occupy different slots in the noun phrase.
Content 1: \gll Pē ira a \textbf{kuā} \textbf{Tiare} i iri ai ki \ꞌuta e tahi mahana. | \gls like ANA PROP COLL Tiare PFV ascend PVP to inland NUM one day | \glt ‘Thus Tiare and the others went to the countryside one day.’
Content 2: \gll He nonoho \textbf{a} \textbf{kuā} \textbf{koro} he kakai. | \gls NTR PL:sit PROP COLL Dad NTR PL:eat | \glt ‘Dad and the others sat down and ate.’
Content 3: \gll E Tiare, e hāpa\ꞌo rivariva koe i a \textbf{kuā} \textbf{māhaki}. | \gls VOC flower EXH care_for good:RED 2SG ACC PROP COLL companion | \glt ‘Tiare, take good care of the little ones.’

Knowledge Point: Secondly, unlike the proper article a, kuā occurs after the preposition o, as in \REF{ex:5.11} above.
Content 1: \gll ¿O \textbf{kuā} \textbf{kōrua} i aŋa? | \gls ~of COLL 2PL PFV make | \glt ‘Did you (pl.) make it together?’

Knowledge Point: In the fourth place, unlike the proper article, kuā can be followed by the plural marker ŋā\is{nza (plural marker)@ŋā (plural marker)}, as in \REF{ex:5.13} above.
Content 1: \gll Ko \textbf{kuā} \textbf{tō\ꞌoku} ŋā poki taina rikiriki era ko tō\ꞌoku pāpārū\ꞌau era. | \gls PROM COLL POSS.1SG.O PL child sibling small:PL:RED DIST PROM POSS.1SG.O grandfather DIST | \glt ‘We were with my little brothers and my grandfather.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, kuā occurs in the vocative\is{Vocative}, as in \REF{ex:5.12} above, something which is not possible with a.
Content 1: \gll Ka oho mai, e \textbf{kuā} \textbf{repa} ē. | \gls IMP go hither VOC COLL young_man VOC | \glt ‘Come, my friends.’

Knowledge Point: The quantifier \textit{me{\ꞌ}e rahi} ‘many/much’ (\sectref{sec:4.4.7.1}) excludes the use of a determiner; this means it cannot occur at all in noun phrases preceded by a preposition. (In this case, speakers may resort to using the adjective rahi ‘many/much’ as an alternative strategy, see \REF{ex:4.102} on p.~\pageref{ex:4.102}.)
Content 1: \gll He ha\ꞌere mo haka ora \ꞌi te rohirohi o tū \textbf{aŋa} \textbf{rahi} era. | \gls NTR walk for CAUS live at ART tired:RED of DEM work many/much DIST | \glt ‘He went to rest from the fatigue of those many works.’

Subsubsection: Contexts in which determiners are excluded\label{sec:5.3.2.2
Knowledge Point: In these cases the noun phrase does not refer to any house in particular: hare era in \REF{ex:5.20} does not refer to a certain house, but to houses in general. In other words, the noun phrase is non-referential\is{Referentiality}. If the article were used (ki te hare era), the noun phrase would refer to a \is{Specific reference}specific house.
Content 1: \gll He e\ꞌa rā matu\ꞌa Iporito \textbf{ki} \textbf{hare} \textbf{era} \textbf{ki} \textbf{hare} \textbf{era}. | \gls NTR go_out DIST parent Hippolyte to house DIST to house DIST | \glt ‘Father Hippolyte went here and there (lit. to that house to that house).’

Subsubsection: Contexts in which t{-determiners are optional\label{sec:5.3.2.3
Knowledge Point: Sometimes the determiner is omitted in sentence-initial noun phrases which contain a postnominal demonstrative\is{Demonstrative!postnominal} (nei, ena or era). The noun phrase may be the subject of a verbal \REF{ex:5.23} or nominal clause\is{Clause!nominal} \REF{ex:5.24}, or a left-dislocated\is{Dislocation!left} constituent \REF{ex:5.25}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nu\ꞌu} \textbf{nei} ko hoki mai \ꞌā mai Tahiti ki Rapa Nui. | \gls people PROX PRF return hither CONT from Tahiti to Rapa Nui | \glt ‘These people had returned from Tahiti to Rapa Nui.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Kai} \textbf{ena} i a kōrua, kai rivariva. | \gls food MED at PROP 2PL food good:RED | \glt ‘That food you have is good food.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Taŋata} \textbf{nei} ko Pāpu\ꞌe, \ꞌi Mā\ꞌea Makohe tō\ꞌona hare. | \gls man PROX PROM Papu’e at Ma’ea Makohe POSS.3SG.O house | \glt ‘This man Papu’e, his house was in Ma’ea Makohe.’

Subsection: The function of the article te\label{sec:5.3.3
Knowledge Point: Te can be used with count nouns as in \REF{ex:5.28}, mass nouns as in \REF{ex:5.29}, and abstract concepts as in \REF{ex:5.30}:
Content 1: \gll He tu\ꞌu mai \textbf{te} taŋata, \textbf{te} vi\ꞌe, he popo mai ki roto ki \textbf{te} hare. | \gls NTR arrive hither ART man ART woman NTR pack hither to inside to ART house | \glt ‘Men and women arrived and crowded into the house.’
Content 2: \gll Ko mate atu \ꞌana ki \textbf{te} \textbf{vai} mo unu. | \gls PRF die away CONT to ART water for drink | \glt ‘I’m dying for water to drink.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Te} \textbf{haŋa} rahi pa he manu era he paloma... | \gls ART love much like PRED bird DIST PRED dove | \glt ‘Great love is like a dove...’

Subsection: The function of the article te\label{sec:5.3.3
Knowledge Point: A noun phrase is also non-specific\is{Specific reference!non-specific reference} when its referent is hypothetical. This happens for example when the item is desired or sought as in (\ref{ex:5.34}–\ref{ex:5.35}), denied as in \REF{ex:5.36}, or its existence is questioned as in \REF{ex:5.37}. In all these examples, the referent has not been mentioned in the preceding context, but even so, te is used:
Content 1: \gll ...mo ai o te moni mo ho\ꞌo mai i \textbf{te} \textbf{haraoa}. | \gls ~~~for exist of ART money for trade hither ACC ART bread | \glt ‘(He sells food) in order to have money to buy bread.’
Content 2: \gll He kī ō\ꞌoku ki tō\ꞌoku ŋā poki taina era mo oho o mātou mo kimi i \textbf{te} \textbf{pipi}. | \gls NTR say POSS.1SG.O to POSS.1SG.O PL child sibling DIST for go of 1PL.EXCL for search ACC ART shell | \glt ‘I told my brothers and sisters that we would go to look for shells.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌIna ko kai i \textbf{te} \textbf{kai} mata. | \gls NEG NEG.IPFV eat ACC ART food raw | \glt ‘Don’t eat raw food.’
Content 4: \gll —¿E ai rō \ꞌā \textbf{te} \textbf{ika} o roto? —\ꞌIna e tahi. | \gls ~~~~IPFV exist EMPH CONT ART fish of inside ~~~NEG~ NUM one | \glt ‘—Are there any fish inside? —Not one.’

Subsection: The function of the article te\label{sec:5.3.3
Knowledge Point: when the noun itself is questioned by the interrogative adjective hē ‘which’: see example \REF{ex:5.18} in \sectref{sec:5.3.2.2}.
Content 1: \gll ¿\ꞌI \textbf{kona} \textbf{hē} te māmoe nei? | \gls ~at place CQ ART sheep PROX | \glt ‘Where is this sheep?’

Subsection: The function of the article te\label{sec:5.3.3
Knowledge Point: when the noun phrase occurs immediately after the negator \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} (\sectref{sec:10.5.1}, esp. (\ref{ex:10.94}–\ref{ex:10.96})):\footnote{Notice that the use of he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)} rather than te in this example cannot be explained as an existential construction. This sentence is not a negation of ‘there was an old woman who went down to Hanga Roa’, but refers to a definite woman, as the demonstrative nei indicates. Even so, the negation triggers the use of the predicate marker instead of the referential article.}
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna \textbf{he} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} \textbf{nei} he turu mai ki Haŋa Roa. | \gls NEG PRED old_woman PROX NTR go_down hither to Hanga Roa | \glt ‘This old women did not go down to Hanga Roa.’
Content 2: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō \textbf{he} \textbf{mata} o Hotu \ꞌIti he taŋitaŋi ki te Tūpāhotu? | \gls ~~NEG really PRED tribe of Hotu Iti PRED cry:RED to ART Tupahotu | \glt ‘The tribe of Hotu Iti doesn’t mourn for the Tupahotu, does it?’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, he it is excluded when the noun phrase contains a prenominal numeral. Here is an example with a noun phrase following the negation \textit{{\ꞌ}ina}, a context in which normally he would be used (see \ref{ex:5.48} above):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌIna} \textbf{he} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} \textbf{nei} he turu mai ki Haŋa Roa. | \gls NEG PRED old_woman PROX NTR go_down hither to Hanga Roa | \glt ‘This old woman did not go down to Hanga Roa.’

Knowledge Point: Like other determiners, he can signal nominalisation of a verb; see \REF{ex:3.23} on p.~\pageref{ex:3.23} for an example.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI rā noho iŋa \textbf{he} \textbf{tu\ꞌu} nō mai \textbf{te} \textbf{aŋa} o te nu\ꞌu pa\ꞌari ki tō\ꞌoku koro u\ꞌi. | \gls at DIST stay NMLZ PRED arrive just hither ART do of ART people adult to POSS.1SG.O Dad look | \glt ‘At that time the old people always came to see my father (lit. just arriving was the doing of the old people).’

Knowledge Point: Here are two examples of prenominal numerals in referential noun phrases, as subject \REF{ex:5.56} and direct object \REF{ex:5.57}, respectively:
Content 1: \gll He poreko \textbf{e} \textbf{toru} poki. | \gls NTR born NUM three child | \glt ‘Three children were born.’
Content 2: \gll He aŋa \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi} paepae. | \gls NTR make NUM one shack | \glt ‘He built a shelter.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, if prenominal numerals are determiners, this also explains why they are excluded after the instrumental preposition hai, which precludes the use of a determiner: in order to use a numeral after hai, the numeral must occur after the noun (see \REF{ex:5.65} in \sectref{sec:5.4.2} below).
Content 1: \gll E \ꞌauhau era \ꞌi te \ꞌāva\ꞌe \textbf{hai} māmoe \textbf{e} \textbf{hā}. | \gls IPFV pay DIST at ART month INS sheep NUM four | \glt ‘He was paid four sheep (lit. with four sheep) per month.’

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \sectref{sec:5.3.2.1}, prenominal numerals cannot be preceded by a preposition. As a consequence, they occur most commonly in noun phrases functioning as subject or direct object\footnote{\label{fn:258}The same constraint applies in \ili{Tahitian}: with prenominal numerals, the object marker is omitted (\citealt[184]{LazardPeltzer2000}).} (see (\ref{ex:5.56}–\ref{ex:5.57}) in \sectref{sec:5.3.5} above); however, the noun phrase may also be an oblique argument\is{Oblique} \REF{ex:5.61} or adjunct \REF{ex:5.62}. Without a prenominal marker, the noun phrase in \REF{ex:5.61} would be preceded by the preposition ki ‘to’, while the adjunct noun phrase in \REF{ex:5.62} would be preceded by \textit{{\ꞌ}i} ‘in, at’.
Content 1: \gll He poreko \textbf{e} \textbf{toru} poki. | \gls NTR born NUM three child | \glt ‘Three children were born.’
Content 2: \gll He aŋa \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi} paepae. | \gls NTR make NUM one shack | \glt ‘He built a shelter.’
Content 3: \gll E ko \ꞌavai e au \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi} taŋata i tā\ꞌaku poki. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV give AG 1SG NUM one person ACC POSS.1SG.A child | \glt ‘I won’t give my child to anybody.’
Content 4: \gll He noho \textbf{e} \textbf{toru} marama \ꞌi Aro Huri. | \gls NTR stay NUM three month at Aro Huri | \glt ‘He stayed three months in Aro Huri.’
Content 5: \gll E ko \ꞌavai e au \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi} taŋata i tā\ꞌaku poki. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV give AG 1SG NUM one person ACC POSS.1SG.A child | \glt ‘I won’t give my child to anybody.’
Content 6: \gll He noho \textbf{e} \textbf{toru} marama \ꞌi Aro Huri. | \gls NTR stay NUM three month at Aro Huri | \glt ‘He stayed three months in Aro Huri.’

Knowledge Point: Constructions like \REF{ex:5.61} above are somewhat rare, though; it is unusual for the preposition ki to be omitted.
Content 1: \gll E ko \ꞌavai e au \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi} taŋata i tā\ꞌaku poki. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV give AG 1SG NUM one person ACC POSS.1SG.A child | \glt ‘I won’t give my child to anybody.’

Knowledge Point: When the noun phrase is preceded by a preposition requiring a determiner (\sectref{sec:5.3.2.1}), numerals must be placed after the noun. Here are examples with possessive o \REF{ex:5.63}, and the preposition i after a locational\is{Locational} \REF{ex:5.64}:\footnote{\label{fn:259}The only case in which a numeral does occur after a locative expression, is when the noun phrase is headless\is{Noun phrase!headless}. In the following example, the noun phrase e tahi o kōrua consists of a numeral phrase and a possessive; there is no head noun.
Content 1: \gll te hare \textbf{o} \textbf{te} taŋata \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi} | \gls ART house of ART man NUM one | \glt ‘the house of one man’
Content 2: \gll He eke ki ruŋa \textbf{i} \textbf{te} mā\ꞌea \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi}. | \gls NTR go_up to above at ART stone NUM one | \glt ‘He climbed on a stone.’

Knowledge Point: \sectref{sec:5.4.1} above describes contexts in which the numeral can be prenominal. This does not mean that the numeral must be prenominal in these contexts. Syntactically, in most of these cases the numeral can be placed after the noun as well. Here are examples with a postnominal numeral in a subject noun phrase \REF{ex:5.68} and a direct object noun phrase \REF{ex:5.69}:
Content 1: \gll He oho mai te Miru \textbf{e} \textbf{rua}, ko Tema ko Pau \ꞌa Vaka. | \gls NTR go hither ART Miru NUM two PROM Tema PROM Pau a Vaka | \glt ‘Two Miru men came, Tema and Pau a Vaka.’
Content 2: \gll He tute mai i te moa \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi}. | \gls NTR chase hither ACC ART chicken NUM one | \glt ‘He chased a (lit. one) chicken.’

Knowledge Point: In cases like (\ref{ex:5.68}–\ref{ex:5.69}) the choice between pre- and postnominal numerals is syntactically free; however, there may be a subtle difference in meaning. This is especially the case with e tahi ‘one’. In prenominal position, e tahi tends to have a \is{Specific reference!non-specific reference}non-specific sense. This sense is especially clear after negations, when tahi can often be translated as ‘any’:
Content 1: \gll He oho mai te Miru \textbf{e} \textbf{rua}, ko Tema ko Pau \ꞌa Vaka. | \gls NTR go hither ART Miru NUM two PROM Tema PROM Pau a Vaka | \glt ‘Two Miru men came, Tema and Pau a Vaka.’
Content 2: \gll He tute mai i te moa \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi}. | \gls NTR chase hither ACC ART chicken NUM one | \glt ‘He chased a (lit. one) chicken.’

Knowledge Point: Secondly, when the noun is subject of a verb which has a plural form as in \REF{ex:5.78}, or is modified by a plural adjective.
Content 1: \gll He ŋaro tū pere\ꞌoa era, he \textbf{ŋāŋaro} \textbf{te} \textbf{va\ꞌehau}. | \gls NTR disappear DEM car DIST NTR PL:disappear ART soldier | \glt ‘The carriage disappeared and the soldiers disappeared.’

Knowledge Point: In conclusion, ŋā can be omitted when it is clear that reference is plural. However, this does not mean that ŋā is only used when there is no other clue for plurality. It may co-occur with a numeral or other quantifier\is{Quantifier} as in \REF{ex:5.80} or a plural verb form as in \REF{ex:5.81}:
Content 1: \gll He e\ꞌa mai tou \textbf{ŋāŋata} \textbf{e} \textbf{ono} mai roto mai te hare ki haho. | \gls NTR go_out hither DEM men NUM six from inside from ART house to outside | \glt ‘Those six men came out of the house.’
Content 2: \gll Ko \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌara} \ꞌana tū ŋā vārua era. | \gls PRF PL:wake_up CONT DEM PL spirit DIST | \glt ‘Those spirits woke up.’

Knowledge Point: It can be used for items forming a group as in \REF{ex:5.86}, or for a plurality of separate items as in \REF{ex:5.87}:\footnote{\label{fn:264}Pace \citet[135]{DuFeu1996}; \citet[485]{DuFeu1987}.}
Content 1: \gll I taŋi era te oe, he tāhuti tahi \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{poki} he haka kāuŋa. | \gls PFV cry DIST ART bell NTR PL:run all ART PL child NTR CAUS line_up | \glt ‘When the bell sounded, all the children ran and stood in line.’
Content 2: \gll Te nua rakerake mo te \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{me\ꞌe} ha\ꞌere tahaŋa nō a te ara. | \gls ART cloth_cape bad:RED for ART PL thing walk aimlessly just by ART road | \glt ‘The ordinary capes were for the ones (=people) who just walked along the road.’

Subsection: Co-occurrence of ŋā and the determiner\label{sec:5.5.2
Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:5.88} and \REF{ex:5.89} the noun is kope. (Kōrua) ko ŋā kope is more or less a frozen expression, though \REF{ex:5.89} shows that it also occurs without ko. It expresses endearment: ‘those dear boys’.
Content 1: \gll ¿Ki hē kōrua ko \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{kope}? | \gls ~to CQ 2PL PROM PL person | \glt ‘Where are you going, guys?’
Content 2: \gll Ka raŋi \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{kope} ka oho mai. | \gls IMP call PL person IMP go hither | \glt ‘Call the guys to come.’
Content 3: \gll Ka raŋi \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{kope} ka oho mai. | \gls IMP call PL person IMP go hither | \glt ‘Call the guys to come.’

Subsection: Co-occurrence of ŋā and the determiner\label{sec:5.5.2
Knowledge Point: The noun phrase in \REF{ex:5.90} can be regarded as similar to a name: ŋā poki o Miru ‘the Miru people’. Rapa Nui has more cases where names are introduced by ŋā:
Content 1: \gll E tahi pihi o te ta\ꞌu o \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{poki} o Miru, he ora haka\ꞌou \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{poki} o Tūpāhotu. | \gls NUM one decade of ART year of PL child of Miru NTR live again PL child of Tupahotu | \glt ‘After ten years of (the reign of) the children of Miru, the children of Tupahotu revived.’

Subsection: Co-occurrence of ŋā and the determiner\label{sec:5.5.2
Knowledge Point: \REF{ex:5.91} may be an example of non-referential\is{Referentiality} use. In such expressions the noun phrase does not refer to any house, but to houses in general. (See (\ref{ex:5.20}–\ref{ex:5.21}) on p.~\pageref{ex:5.20}.)
Content 1: \gll He oho au ki \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{hare} he no\ꞌino\ꞌi hai kona mahute. | \gls NTR go 1SG to PL house NTR request:RED INS place mulberry | \glt ‘I’m going to the houses to ask for mulberry fibres.’
Content 2: \gll He e\ꞌa rā matu\ꞌa Iporito \textbf{ki} \textbf{hare} \textbf{era} \textbf{ki} \textbf{hare} \textbf{era}. | \gls NTR go_out DIST parent Hippolyte to house DIST to house DIST | \glt ‘Father Hippolyte went here and there (lit. to that house to that house).’
Content 3: \gll He oho \textbf{hare} \textbf{\ꞌiti} \textbf{hare} \textbf{nui} ki te taŋata. | \gls NTR go house small house big to ART man | \glt ‘He went to all the houses (lit. small house big house) to the people.’

Knowledge Point: In other cases it is also possible to leave out the noun after a t{}-possessive\is{Pronoun!possessive!t-class} pronoun. The implied head noun may be expressed in a preceding clause as in \REF{ex:5.100}, or not at all as in \REF{ex:5.101}.
Content 1: \gll Ka rova\ꞌa e Hete i te māmari ka puā tako\ꞌa a Kikio ki \textbf{tā\ꞌana}. | \gls CNTG obtain AG Hete ACC ART egg CNTG touch also PROP Kikio to POSS.3SG.A | \glt ‘When Hete got an egg, Kikio also touched his (one).’
Content 2: \gll He va\ꞌai \textbf{tā\ꞌana}, \textbf{tā\ꞌana}, he tuha\ꞌa. | \gls NTR give POSS.3SG.A POSS.3SG.A NTR distribute | \glt ‘He gave everyone his share, distributing it.’

Knowledge Point: We may therefore assume a distinction between modifiers as part of a compound\is{Compound} and modifiers in a post-nominal modifier position; in other words: noun adjuncts versus noun phrase adjuncts. This coincides with another syntactic difference: the order of elements within a compound\is{Compound} is fixed, while the relative order of adjectives is sometimes free ((\ref{ex:5.135}–\ref{ex:5.136}) on p.~\pageref{ex:5.135}).
Content 1: \gll He aŋa i te hare \textbf{teatea} \textbf{nuinui}. | \gls NTR make ACC ART house white:RED big:RED | \glt ‘He built a big white house.’
Content 2: \gll He aŋa i te hare \textbf{nuinui} \textbf{teatea}. | \gls NTR make ACC ART house big:RED white:RED | \glt ‘He built a big house, which was white.’

Knowledge Point: modifiers closer to the noun are semantically closer to it as well. This is illustrated in \REF{ex:5.107} above; see also (\ref{ex:5.135}–\ref{ex:5.136}) on p.~\pageref{ex:5.135};
Content 1: \gll te \ob\textbf{pū\ꞌoko} \textbf{haka} \textbf{tere}\,\cb \ob\textbf{ta\ꞌe} \textbf{tano}\,\cb era o te hare ture | \gls ART {\db}head CAUS run {\db}CONNEG correct DIST of ART house judgment | \glt ‘the unrighteous head of the courthouse’
Content 2: \gll He aŋa i te hare \textbf{teatea} \textbf{nuinui}. | \gls NTR make ACC ART house white:RED big:RED | \glt ‘He built a big white house.’
Content 3: \gll He aŋa i te hare \textbf{nuinui} \textbf{teatea}. | \gls NTR make ACC ART house big:RED white:RED | \glt ‘He built a big house, which was white.’

Knowledge Point: Compounds may also consist of three members. The third word is a noun \REF{ex:5.122}, verb \REF{ex:5.123} or adjective \REF{ex:5.124} modifying the second noun; together they modify the head noun. (On modifying verbs, see \sectref{sec:5.7.2.3} below.)
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Both of these are among the many instances in Rapa Nui where a nominal construction serves to express an event (\sectref{sec:3.2.5}).} These compounds may appear in any nominal context, just like any noun or noun compound\is{Compound}. (In (\ref{ex:5.128}–\ref{ex:5.129}), the compound\is{Compound} is the predicate of a nominal clause\is{Clause!nominal}.)
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI tō\ꞌona mahana he ai mai te aŋa he \textbf{\ꞌāua} \textbf{titi}, \ꞌo he \textbf{rau} \textbf{kato}. | \gls at POSS.3SG.O day NTR exist hither ART work PRED enclosure build or PRED leaf pick | \glt ‘On certain days there were jobs like making fences or picking leaves.’
Content 2: \gll He \textbf{kai} \textbf{toke} nō mai o te taŋata te aŋa. | \gls PRED food steal just hither of ART man ART do | \glt ‘Stealing the people’s food was what she did all the time.’{\rmfnm}

Knowledge Point: In the first place, a bare relative clause\is{Clause!relative!bare} is still a clause: the verb is part of a verb phrase which may contain postverbal particles, such as iho in \REF{ex:5.130}. Moreover, arguments of the verb may be expressed by independent case-marked noun phrases, such as the subject e ia (with agentive marking) in \REF{ex:5.131}.
Content 1: \gll He aŋa i te paepae e tahi \ꞌi tu\ꞌa o tō\ꞌona hare \ꞌāpī \textbf{aŋa} \textbf{iho}. | \gls NTR make ACC ART shack NUM one at back of POSS.3SG.O house new do just_then | \glt ‘He built a shelter behind his new house he had just built.’
Content 2: \gll He \ꞌamo tahi mai ia i tū ŋā kai \textbf{haka} \textbf{rito} \textbf{era} \textbf{e} \textbf{ia}. | \gls NTR carry all hither then ACC DEM PL food CAUS ready DIST AG 3SG | \glt ‘He carried all that food he had prepared.’

Knowledge Point: That these combinations are compounds is clear from the fact that the noun is not preceded by a determiner, nor by a preposition indicating its semantic role. (For example, the instrumental role would normally be indicated by hai.) Also, postverbal particles follow the noun (nei in \REF{ex:5.134} above), showing that the noun has been incorporated into the verb phrase.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌE nu\ꞌu ta\ꞌe rahi \ꞌi te ra\ꞌā nei e \textbf{\ꞌaroha} \textbf{rapa} \textbf{nui} nei. | \gls and people CONNEG many at ART day PROX IPFV greet Rapa Nui PROX | \glt ‘Few people today greet each other in Rapa Nui (with this Rapa Nui greeting).’

Knowledge Point: As \REF{ex:5.109} shows, the noun phrase may contain more than one adjective. The order of the adjectives is not fixed:
Content 1: \gll Ka ma\ꞌu mai ta\ꞌa pokopoko teatea \textbf{tuki} \textbf{tōuamāmari}. | \gls IMP carry hither POSS.2SG.A container white:RED dot yellow | \glt ‘Bring your white, yellow-dotted bowl.’

Knowledge Point: The adjective may be followed by an intensifying adverb\is{Adverb} rahi ‘much’, \textit{\mbox{ri{\ꞌ}ari{\ꞌ}a}} ‘very, terribly’, \textit{taparahi-ta{\ꞌ}ata} ‘terribly’ (a \ili{Tahitian} phrase which literally means ‘killing people’), tano ‘in a moderate degree’, mau (in \REF{ex:5.142}, emphasised by the identity particle \textit{{\ꞌ}ā}):
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI nei i nonoho i u\ꞌi ai kāiŋa \textbf{rivariva} \textbf{mau} \textbf{\ꞌā}. | \gls at PROX PFV PL:stay PFV look PVP homeland good really IDENT | \glt ‘Here they stayed and saw that it was a really good country.’

Knowledge Point: The adjective may also be followed by a prepositional phrase as in \REF{ex:5.143}:
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI Haŋa Roa te nonoho haŋa, \ꞌi te kona \ob\textbf{hāhine} \ob\textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌōpītara} \textbf{tuai} \textbf{era}\,\cb\,\cb. | \gls at Hanga Roa ART PL:stay NMLZ at ART place {\db}near {\db}to ART hospital ancient DIST | \glt ‘They lived in Hanga Roa, in a place close to the old hospital.’

Section: Adverbs and nō in the noun phrase\label{sec:5.8
Knowledge Point: In initial subject NPs, nō indicates that the set referred to by the noun phrase has only one entity, viz. the one described in the rest of the sentence. The sentence can be paraphrased as: ‘There is only one [NP], and that is [rest of sentence]’, or more simply: ‘[rest of sentence] is the only [NP].’ For example in \REF{ex:5.144}: ‘There was only one thing on board, and that was a piece of pumpkin’, or ‘A piece of pumpkin was the only thing on board.’
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Te} \textbf{me\ꞌe} \textbf{nō} o ruŋa, he parehe mautini, he oti mau nō. | \gls the thing just of above PRED piece pumpkin NTR finish really just | \glt ‘The only thing (they had with them) on board was a piece of pumpkin, that was all.’

Section: Adverbs and nō in the noun phrase\label{sec:5.8
Knowledge Point: With noun phrases in other positions, nō signals that the rest of the sentence applies only to the entities described by the noun phrase with nō. The sentence can be paraphrased as: ‘only for [NP] is it true that [rest of sentence]’. For example in \REF{ex:5.146}: ‘Only for lobster and crab is it true that they fished with it’; in other words: ‘Lobster and crabs were the only (bait) they fished with.’
Content 1: \gll Te taŋata o nei e hī era \textbf{hai} \textbf{\ꞌura} \textbf{nō} rāua ko te pīkea. | \gls ART man of PROX IPFV to_fish DIST INS lobster just 3PL PROM ART crab | \glt ‘The people here used to fish only with lobster and crab.’

Section: Adverbs and nō in the noun phrase\label{sec:5.8
Knowledge Point: This is also common with nō in predicate noun phrases. Nō indicates that there is only one entity to which the subject applies, viz. the one referred to in the noun phrase containing nō. The sentence can be paraphrased as: ‘Only [predicate] is [subject]’, or more naturally: ‘[predicate] is the only [subject].’ This happens for example in the identifying clause\is{Clause!identifying} (\sectref{sec:9.2.2}) in \REF{ex:5.148} below: ‘Only she was the new child inside’ = ‘She was the only new child inside.’
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{ia} \textbf{nō} te poki \ꞌāpī o roto. | \gls PROM 3SG just ART child new of inside | \glt ‘She was the only new child inside (the class).’

Section: Adverbs and nō in the noun phrase\label{sec:5.8
Knowledge Point: Nō is used in a number of expressions indicating a contrast. The noun phrase te N nō, placed initially in the clause, functions as a connective which signals that the following clause is an exception to what has been stated before. An appropriate translation is ‘however’. The noun may express how this contrast is to be evaluated, whether negatively as in \REF{ex:5.151}, positively as in \REF{ex:5.152}, or neutral as in \REF{ex:5.153}. In \REF{ex:5.151}, the contrast is reinforced with the \ili{Spanish} conjunction\is{Conjunction} pero.
Content 1: \gll Pero \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌino} \textbf{nō}, \ꞌina e tahi materiare mo aŋa. | \gls but ART bad just NEG NUM one material for make | \glt ‘(He wanted to build a house.) But unfortunately (=the problem was), there were no building materials.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Te} \textbf{riva} \textbf{nō}, e ta\ꞌero era, \ꞌina he tiŋa\ꞌi i tā\ꞌana hua\ꞌai. | \gls ART good just IPFV drunk DIST NEG NTR strike ACC POSS.3SG.A family | \glt ‘(He used to drink.) Fortunately (=the good thing was), when he was drunk, he did not beat his family.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Te} \textbf{me\ꞌe} \textbf{nō,} \ꞌi ruŋa i tū vaka era ō\ꞌona e ai rō \ꞌā e tahi pē\ꞌue, e rua miro \ꞌi te kaokao o te vaka. | \gls ART thing just at above at DEM boat DIST POSS.3SG.O IPFV exist EMPH CONT NUM one mat NUM two wood at ART side:RED of ART boat | \glt ‘(His boat was like the other ones;) however, in his boat there was a rug, and two poles on the sides of the boat.’
Content 4: \gll Pero \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌino} \textbf{nō}, \ꞌina e tahi materiare mo aŋa. | \gls but ART bad just NEG NUM one material for make | \glt ‘(He wanted to build a house.) But unfortunately (=the problem was), there were no building materials.’

Knowledge Point: It is more accurate to analyse \textit{{\ꞌ}ā/{\ꞌ}ana} in broader terms: it serves as a marker of \textsc{identity}. As such, it can be used in different ways. Sometimes it indicates that the referent of the noun phrase is identical to another referent in the same clause, as in the reflexive\is{Reflexive} examples (\ref{ex:5.154}–\ref{ex:5.155}) above. In other cases it indicates that the referent of the noun phrase is identical to another referent mentioned earlier in the text, as in \REF{ex:5.156}. It may also underline that the referent is identical to an entity known in some other way (‘the same’). Some examples:
Content 1: \gll Ko ri\ꞌari\ꞌa \ꞌana \ꞌi tū māuiui era ō\ꞌona e ma\ꞌu era \ꞌi roto \textbf{i} \textbf{a} \textbf{ia} \textbf{\ꞌā}. | \gls PRF afraid CONT ACC DEM sick DIST POSS.3SG.O IPFV carry DIST at inside at PROP 3SG IDENT | \glt ‘She was afraid of the sickness she carried inside herself.’
Content 2: \gll He noho \ꞌi ruŋa i te mā\ꞌea e tahi, he kī \textbf{ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{ia} \textbf{\ꞌā}... | \gls NTR sit at above at ART stone NUM one NTR say to PROP 3SG IDENT | \glt ‘He sat down on a stone and said to himself...’
Content 3: \gll He kī atu ia e tō\ꞌoku koro era ki a au... \ꞌAi ka kī haka\ꞌou atu \textbf{e} \textbf{ia} \textbf{\ꞌā}... | \gls NTR say away then AG POSS.1SG.O Dad DIST to PROP 1SG there CNTG say again away AG 3SG IDENT | \glt ‘Then my uncle (lit. father) said to me.... Then he himself said again...’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:5.157}, the place where Taparahi sleeps is the same place where he has just eaten. In \REF{ex:5.158}, the island where the person in question is born is the same island where the story is being told.
Content 1: \gll I oti era te kai, he ha\ꞌuru rō \ꞌai a Taparahi \ꞌi tū kona era \textbf{\ꞌā}. | \gls PFV finish DIST ART eat NTR sleep EMPH SUBS PROP Taparahi at DEM place DIST IDENT | \glt ‘When he had finished eating, Taparahi slept at that same place.’
Content 2: \gll I poreko ai a ia \ꞌi te motu mau nei \textbf{\ꞌā} \ꞌi te matahiti 1922. | \gls PFV born PVP PROP 3SG at ART islet really PROX IDENT at ART year 1922 | \glt ‘He was born on this very same island here in the year 1922.’

Knowledge Point: These examples also illustrate the syntax of \textit{{\ꞌ}ā}/\textit{{\ꞌ}ana}: when \textit{{\ꞌ}ā}/\textit{{\ꞌ}ana} follows a noun, the noun phrase also has a demonstrative: usually prenominal (tū in \REF{ex:5.157}), occasionally postnominal (nei in \REF{ex:5.158}). When \textit{{\ꞌ}ana} follows a pronoun, no demonstrative is used.
Content 1: \gll I oti era te kai, he ha\ꞌuru rō \ꞌai a Taparahi \ꞌi tū kona era \textbf{\ꞌā}. | \gls PFV finish DIST ART eat NTR sleep EMPH SUBS PROP Taparahi at DEM place DIST IDENT | \glt ‘When he had finished eating, Taparahi slept at that same place.’
Content 2: \gll I poreko ai a ia \ꞌi te motu mau nei \textbf{\ꞌā} \ꞌi te matahiti 1922. | \gls PFV born PVP PROP 3SG at ART islet really PROX IDENT at ART year 1922 | \glt ‘He was born on this very same island here in the year 1922.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:5.163} below, the noun is modified by a complex adjective phrase ‘smaller than it’. The adjective itself is in its normal position, but its complement ki a ia ‘than it’, which expresses the standard of comparison, is placed after the postnominal demonstrative\is{Demonstrative!postnominal} era. In \REF{ex:5.164}, the whole adjective phrase is placed at the end of the noun phrase, even after the relative clause\is{Clause!relative}:
Content 1: \gll He take\ꞌa ta\ꞌato\ꞌa mai e tāua te ta\ꞌato\ꞌa ma\ꞌuŋa \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{rikiriki} era \textbf{ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{ia}. | \gls NTR see all hither AG 1DU.INCL ART all hill more small:PL:RED DIST to PROP 3SG | \glt ‘We will also see all the mountains smaller than it (=Terevaka).’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI tū hora era ia i u\ꞌi atu ai a Kālia ko te \textbf{me\ꞌe} \textbf{teatea} \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi} \obe take\ꞌa mai era mai ruŋa i tū pahī era\,\cb \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{nuinui} \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{taŋata} \textbf{e} \textbf{tahi}. | \gls at DEM time DIST then PFV look away PVP PROP Kalia PROM ART thing white:RED NUM one {\db}IPFV see hither DIST from above at DEM ship DIST more big:RED to ART man NUM one | \glt ‘At that moment Kalia saw something white, which was seen on the ship, bigger than a man.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Bare appositions} Bare appositions\is{Apposition} may have generic reference, indicating that the head noun belongs to a certain class of referents. In \REF{ex:5.165}, the apposition tells that Renga Roiti belongs to the class of female children.
Content 1: \gll He poreko ko Reŋa Roiti, \textbf{poki} tamahahine. | \gls NTR born PROM Renga Roiti child female | \glt ‘Renga Roiti, a girl, was born.’

Knowledge Point: They may also have \is{Specific reference}specific reference, identifying the head noun with a certain referent. For example, the apposition\is{Apposition} in \REF{ex:5.167} tells that Papeete is the same place as the capital of Tahiti.
Content 1: \gll te kona ko Pape\ꞌete, \textbf{kona} \textbf{rarahi} o Tahiti | \gls ART place PROM Papeete place important of Tahiti | \glt ‘the city of Papeete, the capital of Tahiti’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{He-marked appositions} Appositions introduced by he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)} may also be either specific\is{Specific reference} as in \REF{ex:5.168} or generic as in \REF{ex:5.169}. In the Bible translation, appositions tend to be marked with he, possibly because the translation employs a relatively polished/formal style.
Content 1: \gll He oho ki Vērene \ꞌi Hūrea, \textbf{he} \textbf{kona} poreko o tō\ꞌona hakaara ko Tāvita. | \gls NTR go to Bethlehem at Judea PRED place born of POSS.3SG.O ancestor PROM David | \glt ‘They went to Bethlehem in Judea, the birth place of his ancestor David.’
Content 2: \gll He haka hāhine rā nu\ꞌu ki a Feripe, \textbf{he} \textbf{kope} o Vetetaira. | \gls NTR CAUS near DIST people to PROP Philip PRED person of Bethsaida | \glt ‘Those people approached Philip, a man from Bethsaida.’

Knowledge Point: The examples above illustrate the most common way to express a combination of a common noun and a name: the common noun is the head noun; the name follows as apposition\is{Apposition}, introduced by ko. There are exceptions though: sometimes ko is not used as in \REF{ex:5.176}; sometimes the name precedes the common noun as in \REF{ex:5.177}:
Content 1: \gll Te kona noho o te \ꞌariki \textbf{Hotu} \textbf{Matu\ꞌa} \ꞌi Hiva Mara\ꞌe Reŋa. | \gls ART place stay of ART king Hotu Matu’a at Hiva Mara’e Renga | \glt ‘The place where king Hotu Matu’a lived in Hiva was Mara’e Renga.’
Content 2: \gll He turu a Rovi, he taŋata hāpa\ꞌo i te poki \ꞌa \textbf{Hotu} \textbf{\ꞌariki}. | \gls NTR go_down PROP Rovi PRED man care_for ACC ART child of.A Hotu king | \glt ‘Rovi came down, the man who took care of the child of king Hotu.’

Subsection: Structure of the proper noun phrase\label{sec:5.13.1
Knowledge Point: The determiner position plays a marginal role in personal noun phrases. It can only be filled by possessive pronouns\is{Pronoun!possessive}, and only when the head noun is a kinship term; see \REF{ex:5.198} on p.~\pageref{ex:5.198}. The post-nominal elements are uncommon as well.
Content 1: \gll He \ꞌui iho ia ō\ꞌoku ki \textbf{a} \textbf{tō\ꞌoku} koro era... | \gls NTR ask just_then then POSS.1SG.O to PROP POSS.1SG.O Dad DIST | \glt ‘Then I asked my uncle (lit. father) again...’

Knowledge Point: Usually, the proper article\is{a (proper article)} is omitted before the subject pronoun of an imperative\is{Imperative} clause, as in \REF{ex:5.190}.
Content 1: \gll Ka oho koe. | \gls IMP go 2SG | \glt ‘Go.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{After prepositions ending in -i}\footnote{\label{fn:281} In almost all Polynesian languages a occurs after i, ki and mai, but not after other prepositions. \citet[58]{Clark1976} suggests this can be explained by a morphophonemic rule which deleted a after prepositions ending in a non-high vowel. This rule must have been operative at a stage prior to \is{Proto-Polynesian}Proto-Polynesian, as it affected all Polynesian languages. The fact that a in Rapa Nui does not occur after hai\is{hai (instrumental prep.)} ‘with’ shows that the rule is no longer productive.} When a proper noun is preceded by \textit{{\ꞌ}i/i}\is{i ‘in, at’@{\ꞌ}i ‘in, at’} ‘in, at’, the accusative marker i, mai\is{i (preposition)} ‘from’ or ki\is{ki (preposition)} ‘to’, the proper article is used. When the preposition is mai, the preposition i is added between mai and the proper article (see \REF{ex:4.272} on p.~\pageref{ex:4.272}).
Content 1: \gll Ararua nō pā\ꞌeŋa e tu\ꞌu mai era, mai Tahiti \ꞌe \textbf{mai} \textbf{i} \textbf{a} Tire. | \gls the_two just side IPFV arrive hither DIST from Tahiti and from at PROP Chile | \glt ‘The two sides came, from Tahiti and from Chile.’
